Definitely get this as an app. My friend got the pot of clams which she devoured and I tried the chicken with mash which was perfectly cooked with a nice lemon gravy. Can't wait to come back and try the burgers!
author: Shareen P.

description:
Such a bummer because I had pretty good food at their other location and outstanding service.

Unfortunately. Our experience at the end of our meal really turned me off to patronizing them again.

Our waiter (the person who actually took our order and served us) was lovely and we ordered beef tartare and marguez plate to start. Both were very good!

For entrees we got French onion soup, basic burger, and salmon burger (sans bun). We all agreed that food was good (though not amazing) for the price point and ambiance/location. 

I enjoyed my salmon burger but was hoping for a nice crusty sear on the skin. It tasted steamed/baked and not grilled/broiled. French onion soup looked good but cheese was gloopy and thick as if not melted enough. We all agreed that the French fries here are addictive.

Sadly, at the end of our meal while wrapping up, someone other than our waiter (owner? Manager?) asked us to move because he has people waiting for the table. I HATE being rushed after eating. He asked our party (which had gone from 3 to 2) to get up and reconfigure our 4-top to a 2-top. I told him we were almost done and were in the process of paying for the check. 5 min later, he was back and rudely asked us to move over because "people are waiting." I get that you want to move tables as a restaurant but terrible to hurry diners already seated and trying to finish up their conversation. Literally never had this happen to me at a restaurant. 

One star for our waiter and another for those awesome fries but "service" execution at the end of the meal was whack and far better restaurants in Hayes Valley w/more impressive food and gracious service.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Got an early dinner with a friend on a Froday night around 5:30. We were seated right away, and outside like the Parisians do. 

My friend had eaten here before so he knew what was good. We ordered the Mariniere Mussels and the large beef tartar to split. 

Beef tartar was delicious! Mustardy and creamy with the cracked (raw) quail egg in the middle. I only wish they provided more than just 5 croutons as there was a lot of tartar. 

I've had mussels in France before and the mussels here were ok. I liked them, but some of them at the top were just a little dry. The sauce at the bottom soaked up with a little bread was good and enough to share for two people that love to eat. 

The bread served with the meal was a little stale and sliced somewhat irregularly. It wasn't so bad with a little butter and a soak in a buttery wine garlic sauce though and it didn't stop us for ordering a second basket.

The service was ok, totally standard, although we did fail to get our waiter's attention once or twice. Overall a nice meal outside in the summer.
author: Candice C.

description:
Came here for dinner on Saturday around 9pm after a long day. We had high expectations from the reviews, but found the experience didn't meet them.

Food: 

We ordered moules provençale and fries, the basic burger with salad, and Brussels sprouts and split all the items. 

They dish up good sized portions on everything, which is nice. Hands down our two side items (fries and sprouts) were the best-- crispy and well prepared. 

The mussels were disappointing. About a third were completely closed and undercooked, very difficult to get out of the shell, and tasted gross and fishy. Also, the flavor of the sauce wasn't really evident. 

The burger was meh as well-- not a whole lot of taste to speak of, and the roll was twice as big as the meat, it should have been cut smaller. Also, it came with caramelized onions and tomato on the side, but the onions were served ice cold, which I'd never seen before. The onions didn't add much flavor either.

The side salad was solid, nothing to write home about. The sliced baguette they served us before the meal was however quite dry.

Service: 

We were seated about 15 minutes after we arrived-- awesome for a weekend night without a reservation. The hostess was also considerate and gave us the one available table (eating at the bar was our original option and they don't have different lists for the two). 

The food came out very quickly-- almost too quickly. I suspect that's why the mussels were raw, they didn't take much time to prepare them. It was incredibly busy as well so waiters weren't really going around to refill water or check on us, we had to ask.

Overall rating is below middling since some of the food was good and the service was ok given that they were quite busy. Probably won't be going back.
author: Caroline A.

description:
This restaurant has a very nice outdoor seating area, extremely ideal for lunch on a sunny day. Service was great. Everyone was nice but not overly attentive. This is good for me personally because I hate being interrupted while my mouth is full of food to answer a server's question on how my meal is. I ordered the escargots and pork chop. The escargots were flavorful and the sauce was perfect to dip your bread in. The pork chop was covered in delicious sauce and garnish, albeit a bit dry. 
Overall, I had a great experience. I would come back to this establishment again.
author: Catherine T.

description:
I've never had a good French food experience. Tried onion soup at a young age and immediately spat it out. Had tartare at an actual Parisian restaurant and couldn't get over the fact that I was eating stuff that was meant to be cooked. Stayed away from escargot because snails?? The icky things on my sidewalk? No thanks. 

I was ordering the wrong food, I guess. I came to Chez Maman at around 5pm on a Sunday, and although it was a small place, we were immediately seated. There were still some spots open for 2, and a couple tables were unavailable because they were getting ready for a party of 6. We ordered the mussels in mariniere (garlic, lemon juice, white wine) broth, a baked salmon crepe, and the veal in cream sauce. The mussels were very impressive. They came in a little pot, steaming and smelling of garlic. They were so fresh, and when I bit into bread that I'd soaked into the broth? Yum. 

The salmon crepe, in contrast, was a bit flavorless. Maybe the richness of the mussels had dominated by taste buds, but I could barely taste the salmon. All I got was the texture of the crepe, and it seemed like the salmon was only a very thin layer. The veal sauce was really creamy; I couldn't stop smelling it because it seemed like it had permeated our entire table space. Whether this is a good or bad thing really depends on if you like cream. I did, so it wasn't a problem at all. The meat wasn't that tender, but the sauce gave it a lot of flavor. 

Next time when I'm braver, I'll come back and try the tartare and escargot.
author: Sophie W.

description:
#overit
I liked my Chicken Crepe because it was saucy.
Grendo unliked his because it was saucy. #twss
C'est la vie, non?
author: Dan B.

description:
Fantastic cute French diner. I had a terrific cheesy French onion soup to start. Loved it!

The free bread was terrible because it was old and half of the pieces were stale. If you want bread it looks like you need to pay for the good stuff. 

I chose a savory smoked salmon crepe for dinner. The crepe itself was ... not what I expected. It was brown and felt like the tasteless whole wheat of crepes (and not in the great whole wheat bread kind of way). It wasn't bad and didn't take away from the dish, but it definitely didn't add anything. 

The smoked salmon was the best part. The spinach that came with it was slightly bitter and there as way too much. if there was the same amount of salmon and just less spinach, that would be a fine ratio.
author: Ke D.

description: I know this pic was taken on this year of May. This probably be my 1st time tried out at French Restaurant. I really enjoy trying out their food (which I forgot what's it called) and my first dish was very delicious! However, I had a sore throat after the meal. I'm not sure should I order this dish on my next visit and of course I will come by again. Overall, good service and good atmosphere!!
author: Jamie W.

description:
I love this restaurant!!! Very good service
Amazing food, French specialty. We feel like on a French bistro!
The staff is amazing and very friendly!
I'm a huge fan of the salmon and hachis parmentier but my big sins are the chocolate fondant and the tarte tatin...
100% french food
author: Sonya B.

description:
Wine priced reasonably! Tasty French cuisine! Small intimate space! 

Love the warm goat cheese salad, must try.

The beef tartare is so delicious too, id opt for the smaller portion though.

Love the pork chop entree with Brussels sprouts, mariniere mussels are a must, burger is pretty delicious too! Would like to try the veal in the future!

Very authentic, reminds me of a quaint dinner spot in Paris :)
author: Kimia M.

description:
Came here for weekend brunch and there was no wait for 2. Service was really friendly and attentive. There's cozy seating inside and a few tables outside good for people watching.

Getting a burger here is the way to go! We got the basic burger ($12) with avocado and Swiss cheese ($1.50 extra each topping). The burger was so juicy and had a delicious creamy aioli. The ciabatta bread was the perfect texture. I was a huge fan of french fries you can order with it. Soo amazing with the aioli.

We also got the chicken apple sausage omelette ($14) which was filled with cheese, tomatoes, and bell peppers. The sausage was extremely flavorful and the serving size was so filling. The omelette itself was good but nothing memorable compared to the burger.
author: Linda X.

description: Food was delicious! Baked camembert, stripe bass, white wine and mushroom fettuccini and chocolate fondant for dessert. So delicious!
author: erika e.

description:
Delicious food, wonderful staff, and great place! The only down side to this place is the space and the wait time. I only waited because I wasn't that hungry at the time.

We ordered the brussel sprouts, steak & fries, and steamed mussels. Everything was delicious! The brussel sprouts were seasoned very well. The steamed mussels was light with a subtle taste. I loved the steak and fries. The steak was cooked nicely, a medium as I requested. It was very tender and juicy. The fries were yummy. I just wished it had more!

Overall, perfect date spot if you don't mind the wait. It's small and gives off a very cozy and intimate atmosphere, which I loved.
author: Wendy Y.

description: Went today for lunch and I must say, amazing experience. The wait was reasonable even though we had 4 people during a busy President's day. Our waitress was fantastic and she gave us great recommendations. Her advice to order the beef tartare as a starter  which she followed up by recommending the mussels in white wine and garlic, both were spot on. My entire party enjoyed the food and we had a great time. Her authentic french accent really made us feel like we were in Paris. No stone was left unturned at this truly french experience. The service and food were both authentic and amazing. We are definitely coming back very soon!!!
author: Adam G.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant. It was my first time here and the food was delicious and very well priced. The service was excellent our server was very nice and made very well recommendations. I will definitely come back next time i visit SF!
author: Rocky K.

description:
Great spot for if you want good quality food without breaking the bank. Parking is limited to the streets. The dining area, albeit well decorated and vibrant, is a bit small; however, they do have outdoor seating which is good depending on the weather. There is a unisex restroom that is clean. if you have a group of 4 or more expect to wait a while as most of the tables here accommodate smaller groups.

I highly recommend the burgers here. The last time I was here I got the basic burger, but added Brie, mushrooms and avocado. I was surprised on the portion size of the burger. The bread looked massive; however, the meat patty was big enough to where each bite had a substantial portion of it. In addition, the patty was cooked the way I wanted it as well and was very juicy. The fries were on point and went well with the dipping sauce. If you're not craving a burger, I also recommend getting the grilled salmon. The fillet was pretty big and the had a very zesty lemon taste which I enjoyed. 

The service here is very good. The food came on time and the servers were kind and attentive. I definitely enjoyed the two times I dined there and I expect to come back there very soon. 4.5 stars.
author: Jason P.

description:
Had lunch here recently for the first time.
Count me as a fan!  The menu was great.  Almost felt like there were too many good-sounding choices to select from .. that's a nice problem to have.

We had:

French onion soup - nicely done... thick melty gruyere cheese on top
French fries (of course) - delicious; generously sized portion
Salad Nicoise - beautiful slices of seared ahi; nice greens; light but tasty vinaigrette
Roasted 1/2 Chicken w mashed potatoes and pan gravy - totally and completely awesome; wonderfully cooked and presented and the pan gravy was to die for. Seriously - this was the star of the lunch.  

Didn't have room for dessert.  Sigh.

If you are in the area, this is definitely a spot worth visiting.  

I can't wait to come back and try more items on their menu.
author: Lewis C.

description: I had the Croque Mademoiselle for lunch (cheese, salmon, egg). First, the sunny side egg egg came out with clear egg white (yuck!) so I sent it back, and they cooked the egg over easy and brought it back to me. The sandwich was drowning in cheese and too thick bread, with a really meager slice of salmon. For $13, I would expect more. The salad it came with was underdressed, and I requested more dressing. The waitress brought the dressing in a little dish, and it was so thick and emulsified I needed a knife to scoop it out. I added a little salt and pepper, and it helped a little but mostly it needed more vinegar and some additional flavor. Won't be going back.
author: Jane M.

description:
Just dropped by for lunch and ordered the mussels, pear salad (but got the one with goat cheese, tomatoes and eggs..), and ratatouille. Thought the ratatouille was okay, not as flavorful as expected. Mussels were really good; loved the sauce and bacon - went well with the bland bread slices. We got the wrong salad but didn't really care bahah.

Great service and nice outdoor seating too!
author: Juliana P.

description:
A $5 buck Uber ride from our tenderloin hotel on New Year's Eve, this bistro checks off most of the criteria for a celebratory dinner for a reasonable sum. It feels like a neighborhood corner joint -- 2nd err in Lyon, those restos at the entrance to le Marais in the shadow of Le Pompidou, a Brasserie fronting Thompkins in the east village, or one in the plateau in Montreal-- They  serve bistro and Brasserie staples (steak frittes, moules, steak tartare, onion soup). Replete with French speaking bartend and waits.

Except this night, you get the impression that they want to turn the table too too fast by amping up the classic rock music. In this very boomy room.
author: Suburban R.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Thursday night. I put my name down for a party of 2 at around 7:50pm, and we only had to wait 25 minutes to get seated. The restaurant is pretty small, and the layout is very compact. They also have maybe 3 tables of outdoor seating on the sidewalk, which might be nice on a warm night or for brunch, but people waiting for their tables do tend to hang around nearby.

Service was great! Despite the restaurant being packed, our waiter was very attentive, and the food came out really quickly.

A P P E T I Z E R S
1) Escargot - These come in the shells with fancy tongs and small forks to help you pick out the meat. I was really intrigued - I'd never had escargot in the shell before! The meat was juicy and just the right amount of chewy. It comes in a butter and parsley white wine sauce, but the sauce left a little something to be desired. I would have wanted it to be a lot more buttery and have a slightly stronger wine flavor.

E N T R E E S
1) Basic burger + mushrooms + egg with fries - I messed up by not adding cheese to this; it would have made all the difference, but the burger was tasty nonetheless. It comes with two pieces of a rectangular roll sliced in half, instead of a regular bun. The egg was runny, beef patty cooked medium rare, mushrooms piled on top, aioli smothered on the bread. Everything was delicious. It would have been better if the caramelized onions were warm though; they came cold with the veggies and tomato slices.

2) Flat iron steak with fries and green peppercorn sauce - Steak was medium rare and not overcooked. It was on the slightly smaller side, but definitely enough to fill you up. The special green peppercorn sauce on the side added a lot of flavor to the meat.

The fries were so good!! They were not too thick and really crispy, and the aioli is amazing!

At the same intersection as Absinthe, I'd probably pick Absinthe over Chez Maman next time in terms of food. They are at different price points though - Absinthe is a bit more costly - so Chez Maman would be the more everyday choice.
author: Tiffany P.

description: Our waitress was nice, the food was good, the ambiance is nice. Be aware: they only seat full parties. But, if you do sit outside, they won't forget about you, which happens at some restaurants.
author: Ayslin R.

description: Love this place. A bit of wait at times but server is usually really nice about it. The food is amazing. We lick the food plate in the end.
author: Shiya L.

description:
Strike 1:
A hospitality policy that needs to go away:
"We'll seat you when your entire party has arrived."

The restaurant is only partially full.  Three patrons wait outside for their dinner companions to arrive The restaurant starts to fill up with people who's entire party is present.  Three sets of diners grow anxious and hungrier for their partners to arrive.   

Strike 2:
The partner to one of the waiting diners finally arrives!  They request an open table that they sat at a few weeks ago which is a 3 top. They are denied because it's a table for 3.  Will they sit at the bar (with seats with no backs)?  There are no diners with a party of 3 waiting. They are going to deny more comfortable seating so the restaurant can accommodate a party of 3 if one shows up?

Strike 3:
Red wine is served on a warm night.  It's not chilled property.  Who wants to drink a glass of red wine at room temp of 80 degrees?

You're out.  

Food was good but the policy should go away.  Treat your customers well.
author: Jen L.

description: C'est is bon!  Worth the wait for a great experience. The service was extraordinary. We are outside on a cool evening and listened to the sounds of the neighborhood. The steak tartar was flavorful and smooth. The escargot were light and airy. The entrees has great savory flavors. Will be back to this neighborhood gem!
author: S T.

description:
Chez Maman, comfort French Food. Love this location in Hayes Valley. No reservations. Just put your name down, Have a drink in the neighborhood. Service is friendly, causal. Love the window seats, people watching. 

The food is always pretty good. Not a fine dining restaurant but comforting atmosphere and always good food. 

My favorites are their escargot.  Escargot de Bourgogne made with parsley, butter-shallots & white wine. YUM! I can eat two orders of that myself. Also dipping bread into the sauce is amazing, So yummy! 

Also love their French onion soup. LOADED with CHEESE. Love Chez Maman.
author: Sandy B.

description: Amazing! Great service. Amazing food and burgers. Quaint atmosphere. Loved everything about it.
author: Alison A.

description:
Love, love this place! Good French bistro food, wine, beer in a relaxed environment and super reasonable pricing despite being in a prime location in SF! Heck yeah!

I easily ordered the mussels in white wine sauce with frites. I got a big pot full of plump mussels (not the sorry shriveled ones you sometimes get from other places). It also came with a heaping bucket of fries!

Service was so-so but then again, it's a very relaxed French bistro. I got my food and it was good and sometimes, that's all that matters.
author: Carmela A.

description: Steak and fries were heaven, fast staff, great location and a must do.  I highly recommend going here!
author: Kk K.

description:
Top five burger but only if you add the egg. Service is just like France ;). Seriously though never had a bad experience here nor ever left thinking it was a waste. Good food, good vide and all around good spot.

Definitely would recommend, especially for lunch when it's nice outside.
author: Robert E.

description:
It's pretty rare to find a casual french joint in the city! I'm so grateful for Chez Maman for it reminds me so much of France!

I tried this place during lunch and ordered:
Savoyarde crepe with potato, prosciutto & swiss cheese ($12). I really liked everything about this dish! The Arugula salad on top of this crepe was a great addition.

Also ordered the mussels with white wine, garlic and lemon juice sauce ($16) with fries ($5).  I loved thisss. The mussels were nice and meaty and there were tons of and garlic! The white wine sauce was pretty strong so I wouldn't recommend this sauce for those who don't like strong wine taste in their food. The fries were also bomb! - perfectly crispy and it came with garlic aioli ... yumms.
author: Leilani Y.

description: Absolutely loved this place! The food was amazing and the staff was excellent! We will be coming back next time we visit San Francisco.
author: Scott M.

description: I love this little cafe with a few sidewalk tables. My favorite meal before a night at SF Jazz. The french plates are great (muscles, crepes, filet of sole) but then there are great burgers, fries, etc. so there is always something for everyone. Oh, and nice wine and beer choices.
author: Scott E.

description:
Great French food at a good reasonable price - if you're willing to wait. 

The worse part of the experience is the wait. We waited more than an hour. Thankfully they take your name and number and call when you're table is free. 

The escargot is fantastic. Very garlicky but identical to that which I've had throughout France.

The goat cheese salad was great. Nicely dressed and the goat cheese is breaded and baked. 

The flank steak was fantastic. It was much thicker, more tender and flavorful than any I can remember. Frites and mustard were also great.

The Thai mussels were excellent! Great flavor, not loaded with butter or oil, just a great taste. 

Only complaint is that the food is generally over salted though that's not uncommon for French restaurants in America.
author: Kevin V.

description:
I've been here many times and always left impressed. 

The white wine mussels are great to start and to share. 

The salmon was cooked perfectly and i had it with the brussel sprouts which were also very well prepared. 

The steak, another great option. I've ordered both the steak and salmon a few times since they were so good. I'm sure the rest of the menu holds up just as well. 

If the weather Is nice you can take advantage of the outdoor seating which is not super common in SF
author: David S.

description:
To start with, the food was good, interesting, and prompt. However, when I go out to eat with family, the experience and atmosphere of the restaurant plays a big role. Our waiter was nice and polite to start the night, but at the end of the meal when my family was finishing drinking coffee/wine and after the check was paid, he very rudely and to be honest, aggressively asked us to leave the restaurant. I find it difficult to wrap my head around the idea that a waiter, who recently dropped off a $250+ check, is rude and dismissive of the customer. 

It's unfortunate that my family had this experience, because the food was great. But why would we return to a restaurant who treated their customers like that?
author: Aoife A.

description:
My favorite thing to do in Paris is to have a leisurely lunch on a sidewalk somewhere and watch the world go by and Chez Maman reminds me of those places. Simple, well done food, good service, not terribly expensive and you get an eyeful watching the people go by. 

I stopped by to have a light dinner before a rehearsal with the opera and ordered grilled salmon and ratatouille. The salmon was very good, slightly underdone but fresh enough fish to be tasty when raw in the center. It came with some tasty fingerling potatoes. The dish was slightly oily but tasty enough to make that a minor detail. 

Ratatouille is a funny thing for me. It's usually a nice side dish but sometimes it's just wonderful.  At Chez Maman it was nice but not a knockout. (The best I've had was at Cafe Stritch in San Jose. Fab!)

i drank water and didn't have dessert as it was before work and the bill for dinner came to about $25 (and tax deductible!), a bargain for the quality of food and the location.
author: Scott H.

description:
Great neighborhood restaurant!

What to order:
= Baked cambert and garlic toast 
= FRENCH ONION SOUP (best in SF) (ps I'm a native)
= Veal with Cream sauce and mushrooms (my fave)
= Mac and cheese!! 
= Lamb Brochettes 

This place is a gem. Very cute and cozy. Lots of good cheap wine from France. Worth the wait
author: Jean C.

description:
I like this location a great deal more than the Potrero one.

For one, the people watching is more interesting. Not that the people of Potrero are a snorefest;  no no no I'm not looking for any trouble. But let's be real, the corner of Gough and Hayes is definitely more happenin'. Especially on a rare warm SF day, this is one of my favorite spots to grab an outside table and take it all in. Grab a glass, or bottle, of wine and you are set my friend.

Second, and more importantly, the service is faster. I swear at the other location, it takes foreeever to get my food and it's not like they're that swamped. At least when I've gone. Food is more or less the same quality, but if I have a certain hankering for the French bistro offerings of Chez Maman, I'd choose this location over the other.

Going to copy and paste this next section between my reviews for both locations because, like I said, the food quality is pretty consistent (and I'm lazy):
-What everyone orders here: the Chez Maman burger. Best in SF? After years of extensive research, I still couldn't tell you who has the best burger but this is definitely in contention (aka it's really really good)
-What I always order: French onion soup & a) a croque monsieur (served w/ salad), b) a croque mademoiselle w/ smoked salmon (technically a croque norvegien, also w/ salad), c) a nicoise salad, or d) a warm goat cheese salad. For the french onion soup and croque monsieur, I mean come on? Who doesn't love the aesthetics of melted gruyere stretching from dish to mouth?! *droolz*
-What I really recommend: Moules mariniere. Mussels, white wine, lemon juice and parsley-- need I say more? Dip some bread in that sauce and oooo. You. are. bad.
-What I cannot wait to try: Escargot de bourgogne. My bf is not a fan, but this one time the table next to use ordered the escargot and the decadent aroma of garlicky garlicness kept wafting its way over to my nostrils. Give me some. Now.

To be honest, I've never had dinner here so I cannot attest to the quality of actual entrees. But as a soup/salad/sandwich* enthusiast, I really like this place.

Something to note: Brunch is served until 3pm on weekends, not 4pm as their website says.  Not that I've woken up embarrassingly late and have gotten rejected for eggs past 3pm.............
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: This place was awesome! Completely great staff, we were seated quickly at about 6pm. I got the pork chop, with Brussel sprouts in a apple cider mustard sauce. The sauce was delicious, completely complimented the pork and veggies.
author: Haley S.

description: I just love eating here so MUCH it's the first thing I do when I land in SF. Great service and food! Better than in France!
author: Julie F.

description:
So glad we stuck in there and waited for a table. We came around 5:45pm and there was already a 10 table wait ahead of us. And no, they don't take reservations. In total, we waited an hour for a table, but it was SO worth it!

AMBIENCE: Very small and intimate - no more than ~15 tables inside. Low lighting and cramped spaces made it very romantic and what I imagine a quaint restaurant in France would be like! 

SERVICE: Our server came by quickly to take our order and made sure we had enough wine at all times.

DRINK:
We ordered some white wine to go with our mussels. A glass of Chardonnay William Hill & Bordeaux Blanc Chateau. The Chardonnay was a little dry at the finish, but both were pretty sweet and easy to drink. 

FOOD:
+ French onion soup ($7) - The most important thing about French onion is the cheese on top - and this one came hot, melty, and amazing. It was so melty i could lift my spoon 6 inches in the air and it wouldn't break! The beef broth was delicious and the onions and croutons soaked up all the broth wonderfully.

+ Les moules mariniere ($16) - a bucket of mussels in a light white wine, lemon juice, garlic, and parsley broth. The mussels were cooked well and fragrant from the white wine. Take my advice: get fries to dip the broth or soak it all up with bread! You won't want to waste any of the broth even after you've eaten all the mussels.  

+ Chez Maman Mac & Cheese ($14) - This isn't ordinary mac & cheese - it has truffle oil swimming throughout. It was the most delicious thing I've had in a while. It came boiling hot to the table, so we waited for it to cool down before digging in. Which was really hard because you could see the cheese bubbling and smell the truffle wafting up... I'm drooling just from thinking about it. Every bite I had was infused with truffle, which was great with the melted gruyere cheese. The semi-crunchy bread crumbs on top soaked up a lot of truffle oil so it was extra truffle-y.  Please please please order this when you go!

I really wish we could've gotten dessert, but that will have to wait till next time - which may not be too long from now!
author: Venus F.

description:
It's so busy they'll kick you out if you're holding up a table but it's busy because the food is phenomenal and the service is very good while you're eating. 

I've been with a group of 6 of us and got to share a lot of the items and everything was on point.

I would especially recommend the french onion soup.
author: B W.

description: Fantastic food at reasonable price. French onion soup was one of the best I ever had and everything else was good too. Small and busy but well worth the wait.
author: Ki H.

description:
I'll start by saying that this probably would have been 4 stars if it was just a review of the food, but the service was just so terrible that it lost 2 whole stars. 

Firstly, (and I do understand it was a Friday night), but we must have waited at least an hour for a table. We were told multiple times by the host that we were next, which wasn't the case. After we finally got a table we felt pressured to select a drink almost instantly even though we barely saw the menu and like to pick our wine based on what we eat. When we ordered, we told the waitress we were going to share everything and got a mussels, smoked salmon crepe and seasonal veggies and 2 glasses of wine. Within minutes all of our food was delivered at the same time and no drinks at all. We thought it was very strange they brought everything at once as we were sharing and wanted to start with our mussels then move on to the main dish. They gave us attitude when we asked if they could take the veggies and crepe back to the kitchen to keep warm. When we were ready for it, it was cold and we had to request a new one. 

Lastly, we decided we wanted another glass of wine towards the end of dinner. Soon after getting the last glass, the host came up to us and asked that if we weren't going to order more food could we move to another table. At that we asked for the bill and left. 

Considering how long we waited for our table, we were upset that we had felt rushed for the entire evening from the second we sat down and thought it was rude that they asked that we change tables while we were still finishing our drinks. I will not be back again.
author: Emily P.

description: Three of us went to Chez Maman West on a Friday evening before a concert at Symphony Hall.  It was early (5:30), so we were able to get a table immediately, even though it has a very small dining room. .  It is The waitstaff are welcoming and efficient.  The menu is surprisingly extensive.  I ordered moules with frites (mussles and fries). My companions ordered striped bass and Chez Maman "mac and cheese." for entrees.  We shared an endive/pear/walnut/roquefort salad, which was the real star of the dinner.  We had recently returned from a trip to France and were very happy to find a cafe that reminded us of our experiences in Paris and Toulouse.
author: Evelyn G.

description:
The burger boasts a ~1/3lb 100% Angus Beef patty, on a toasted ciabatta roll with aioli (extra aioli on the side), with tomato and caramelized onions on the side.

The beef was well-seasoned with minced onion, herbs, and spices, which complimented the burger with robust and colorful flavors. The patty was also juicy and cooked to an excellent medium-rare. The ciabatta was large, leading to a lot of bread relative to the amount of meat, but soaked the juices and creamy aioli well while retaining a good crunch from the crust.
author: Caleb Y.

description: We were fortunate to get a table on a weekend, since it's quite busy. We ordered the pork chop and half roasted chicken: both were fantastic. The pork chop was done perfectly with the right amount of tenderness, and the sauce it's doused in is literally to die for! Will be back again soon.
author: Shourya K.

description: We came here tonight for my birthday and had a wonderful meal! The service was excellent! From a dessert standpoint, you can't go wrong with the chestnut crepe and chocolate cake. We look forward to returning!!
author: Mary Kathleen S.

description: My burger was great! I know burgers usually tend to be, if you like them, but not all burgers are created equal and the burger here is definitely on. The higher end of the spectrum. Not the best burger I've ever had, but definitely up there! The fries and salad it came with were amazing as well. All the food that I tried was great really! My friend had an amazing salad with salmon that was delicious. My sisters crepe looked great (I didn't try it), and the sparkling rosé they had was very good, especially for the price. My French beer was quite good, my only complaint was that the dogfish Head IPA that I initially wanted was out, along with their other beers on tap, that was just the only one that hadn't had the tap handle removed. In their defense though it was still relatively busy, 3 pm on a Saturday.
author: Makasa H.

description:
Last night I wanted to catch up with a friend and gave him the opportunity to choose the joint. He mentioned this place and I was sold. A cute French restaurant in the Hayes neighborhood? Yes please.

Such a cute, quaint and warm/cozy place. Literally. We walked in and it was toasty hot, but soooo cute! Very small place, so if you don't come early, you'll probably wait, no matter the day of the week. They don't take reservations. At first glance, the place looked like a little French cafe/coffee shop, turned restaurant. Minimal art and decor; simple always goes a long way. Nice bench seating along the window, super comfy. The service was awesome. Multiple people kept checking up on our table to see if we needed anything, but not in an annoying sort of way. They seem to come at just the right time! 

For dinner, I kept it simple. I got the Grilled salmon for $17.The usual order comes with a salmon piece, roasted potatoes, fines herbes and creme fraiche. I typically don't substitute my dishes but I'm on this weird diet so instead of the potatoes, I got a salad. It was a delicious spring mix with olive oil and balsamic dressing. The salmon was perfectly grilled and spiced nicely, although the cut was a bit small for the price tag. No worries, I was content when it was all said and done. If you want your money's worth, though, get the burger. It's less in cost and much bigger with lots of herbed fries. Can you guess what my friend had that evening?!

All in all, I would definitely recommend this place! I can't wait to return and try authentic dishes like the escargot! Come by and check them out!
author: Rockne H.

description: Chez Maman in Hayes Valley is still one of my favorites and an SF institution for authentic French Bistro food.    I was there last night during the Hayes Valley Christmas event and I had a great time.   Enjoyed their famous burger and some escargot.   Perfect!
author: Max K.

description: With Papito, the original Chez Maman location, and to a lesser extent, Mac Daddy already in my dining rotation, choosing Chez Maman West for brunch was a no-brainer. And the way our waiter pronounced my Crêpe Complète with perfect back-of-the-throat tongue rolling -- I still get shivers when I think about it! Comprised of just three ingredients -- four, if you count the over-medium egg -- my buckwheat crêpe was surprisingly filling. I caught myself in a trance, methodically dipping fry after fry in their amazing garlicky aioli; this $6 side is downright addictive. Their entire menu is served for brunch, which means if you're so inclined, you can order a pork chop & brussel sprouts at 10:30am like my friend did. The people behind Chez Maman are nothing if not consistent in churning out meals that make you glad you got your lazy ass out of bed that day.
author: Fancypants X.

description: We ordered the vegetarian fettuccine, the lamb skewers and the sea bass. The food was lackluster at best. The sangria was the only silver lining. The server was somewhat grouchy, and we got far too many not so subtle reminders to finish our meal and leave (being asked if we needed boxes even before we paid etc) - we weren't planning to linger too long as there was a line outside, but we found the nudges quite unnecessary. Overall a below average experience. I had high expectations. I don't think we will be returning.
author: S G.

description:
5 stars for the hostess who kept our seats.
5 stars for wait staff, who kept our glasses filled.
4 stars for the food typical of Bistro fare.

1 star for the rude person telling us they needed the table.

Let me preface this by first covering that I have been a long time patron of the Chez Maman location on Potrero Hill from 15 years ago and my experiences there have always been glowing.  This was the first time I had ever visited this location in Hayes Valley.  Frankly, the horrid traffic/parking nightmares as well as tourist hordes inhibits my traipsing in the area but I was meeting a Googler friend of mine there so proceeded with his plans. 

I ordered the burger, medium rare, with a fried egg on top.  My friend ordered the Eggs Benedict.  My entree reminded me of my meals at Cafe Claude so while the food experience was good, it wasn't exactly blowing my shoes off.  The bun was too chewy and dense so I consumed only 1/2 a bun.  I should have stuck with the Croque Madam but after being in France, I am a bit hesitant to order anything that might jade my experience.

We were sitting there chatting after finishing the meal and barely had the credit card returned when the idiot told us we had to give up our seat.  This is after I noticed others from the establishment looking at our table from the inside of the restaurant as well as lurking behind us since we were seated outside.

My first reaction was that of indignation.  They were telling us to vacate ON TOP of our waiting 40 minutes for the seat in the first place so it seemed
rather back handed.  Second, the last I checked, restaurants are first-come first-serve, so it's not my problem when new clientele choose to show up at 2:30 for brunch when they technically missed the classic brunch window.

His lack of customer service was rude and unacceptable.  I didn't even encounter this type of rudeness when I visited Paris twice this year AND at the Michelin rated establishments I visited!  How very un-French of them.

Will I come back?

Absolutely not.  They don't deserve the patronage.

I'll stick to the original location in Potrero Hill.
author: Miika M.

description:
Best thing about this place was the service, the toasted camembert and the creme brulee. 

We ordered the salmon with potatoes and flat iron steak for entrees and both were ok. The salmon lacked flavor and the potatoes were nothing special. The steak was also just ok, did not have a distinct flavor and the vegetables I ordered with it were sauteed and lacked seasoning. The sauce it came with also didn't pair well with the steak. 

The toasted camembert was very good. It came with toasted bread, roasted garlic, and some salad. It was definitely a great appetizer. The cheese was melted and perfectly spreadable on the toast and tasted fantastic with a piece of roasted garlic. The light lemon salad washed it down very well. 

The creme brulee was extremely good! You must order it, the top wasn't toasted too much to make it hard to crack but perfect enough to break with a single whip of the spoon. It was super creamy and very vanilla-y. It was delicious! My favorite part of the meal!
author: Navene S.

description: I love Chez Maman so much. This place has never let me down. Literally everything on the menu is delicious, but I'm partial to the French Onion Soup and the savory crepes. I tend to prefer it as a lunch spot but Chez Maman works any time of day. Far better than the other French restaurant across the street in my opinion, if you're having a hard time deciding.
author: Tini T.

description:
I had the basic burger with frites and a glass of wine. The last time I came here, I remember the sandwich I had was rich and delicious. This time, the burger was just ok. There is a twinge of something just a little off, and it reminded me of that taste when you cook a burger with meat that's been sitting in your fridge for a few days... 

A minor point, I think the rolls are just a bit too big for the burger. 

Fries are amazing, and I left satisfied. It's definitely a place to visit and try. 

Many patrons around me ordered the French onion soup, the pork chops, or the mussels.
author: Andy C.

description:
I arrived 5 minutes early for a birthday brunch for a friend. There were 7 open tables on Sunday at noon, and no one was waiting.....I wanted to hand them a cake before she arrived. They refused to seat me at a table for 2 until she arrived (even though if I were to dine alone I would still occupy a table for 2). I offered to order in advance so as to not delay their service as they cited that was the reason for not seating me.

After I was seated. The manager came over and explained the policy of how I can't be seated until the other party arrived, and insisted that I order now (as they were handing me menus), and how "customers like you slow us down when there are people waiting"... again 7 open tables in the restaurant, and I already informed the hostess that I would order for both of us....and no other guest were waiting. Ridiculous.  

I went across the street where I was promptly seated and allowed to enjoy my lunch without being told "customers like me..." or being asked to order while the menu is being handed to me.

Customer service is very lacking. I've eaten here before, the food is okay, you can find better lunch spots in the neighborhood. Not worth the bad customer service.
author: N A.

description: Great place for brunches! The place is a bit small and waiting can be long but makes up for it with the food.
author: Hemant J.

description:
Was very disappointed to find out that 2 small bottles of San Pellegrino were $10 ($5 each), if you add tax + tip it adds up to $13 to our dinner total. That's a complete rip off! For $5 it should be a big bottle. It's enough of a reason for me not to come, doesn't seem like the owners are honest, nor do they have any decency for charging that.

Update: someone just private messaged me for this comment called me cheap, a stupid ass and told me to stay at home because it costs the restaurant $5 per bottle (ironically Safeway has it for $1.19). Terrible attitude.
author: Evelyn Z.

description: By far, the best for value for taste and quality in Hayes Valley. The staff is incredibly nice, welcoming, and efficient. The food is heavenly and filling. I recommend starting with Les Moules (mussels) with the Marinière sauce paired with the French Fries w/ Aoli. The Croque Monsieur/Madame are solid appetizer picks too. When t comes to entrees, they're ALL good. Finish with a Suzette Crepe (cool presentation at your table) and a scoop of vanilla gelato to compliment. Chez maman is a SF staple!
author: Chandler G.

description: I went there with a friend for dinner on a Tuesday night. The place was slammed. It took a long time to finally be seated. There aren't many tables, so the wait is usually long every night, since the place is pretty small. The French onion soup is excellent. So was the tuna Niçoise salad I ate. I also ordered the mac & cheese made with truffle oil, which was pricey, but worth what I spent for it. To sum it up, expect Delectable French cuisine, with average ambiance. We were sitting outside, and I wasn't into the hundreds of people buzzing by our tables the entire time, walking up and down Gough St. The heat lamps kept me warm though.
author: Draper O.

description:
Très sympa.

We normally dine after a show. Chez Maman West is open straight-through for lunch and dinner, but is often closed for post-show dining. Needed a pre-show light meal this time, we finally had a chance to try this place. 

The hostess was friendly. Our server spoke French. Loved the menu. Had steak frites and steak tartare (comme plat principal), paired with a glass wine for each. Not the best in town. Yet we did "finis ton assiette" and enjoyably.
author: D.V. A.

description:
Sometimes familiar things are the best things.
With tickets for a wonderful ukulele performance in hand, our challenge on a recent Sunday evening was where to have our pre-performance meal.  
Since Chez Maman doesn't take reservations, my companions came early to sign up for a table.  After a short wait, we were offered a sidewalk table on Hayes Street.  The vibe, the feel, the noise.... never been to France (Europe, much less), but this is what I'd imagine is the norm.  After a short study of their menu, to which my reply to our waiter, "I'd like everything!", as in everything on the menu.  Yes, it was that difficult to choose.  
Here's what I tried and had:

Appetizers
1) Les moules poulette (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=I-ia7EaYhj9wpVv12DegaA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) (shared) - A lighter version and very "parlez vous francaise?" good!  The bacon really went well with the garlic and wine flavors which made the bread dipping unstoppable.

2) French onion soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=iEYcTQqXNcPZ85KxGGh4fA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Remembering the Potrero Hill version being one of the best ever for me, this was a MUST order.  Pretty much as good as the other one, but wished there were more crusty gooey cheese on top.

Main
3) Grilled Pork chop (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Us-HSleQXbDkavBtIRh2Gg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Garnished with Brussels sprouts (love that bacon flavor) and apple cider mustard sauce.  Loved the char flavor on the pork and one chop is perfect for a normal meal.  Finishing my crock of soup, I took half of my chop home for another dinner later in the week.

Being a pre-concert meal, I did not want to interrupt or miss any of Jake's performance due to a nature call so I held back a bit this evening.  Our waiters were cordial and more than willing to joke with us on this balmy Sunday evening; from the hostess to the busboys, everyone had smiles interacting with us.  Tried bites of dining partners' fresh fruit and chestnut crepes, but lost my focus by this time.  Given the crowds that flock to this neighborhood weekend days, we made the right choice for an early dinner here.  Need to fulfill my mission of the "everything" order so you know who will be back!
author: Mike C.

description: Not overly impressed with this little bistro. We enjoyed the pâté appetizer and two different salads. Our veal dishes were over cooked and chewy. To many other restaurants in the area to go back again.
author: Kevin B.

description: Wonderful home style French comfort food and excellent service.  Cozy and truly European in character and charm.  Excellent selection of wines by the glass.  Outstanding hachis parmentier like your French grandmother used to make.
author: Susan W.

description:
Came here on a week night for dinner with a friend. Good selection of food items. The only thing that really stood out to me was the French Onion Soup. That thing as to die for. It's probably 70 percent cheese and 30% soup = bomb.

My friend ordered the frites with mussels. Good amount of mussels, flavors were good. But nothing to rave about. I ordered the tuna nicoise salad. The salad was a generous in portions, but the tuna and salad under dressed for my taste. 

Prices were okay for San Francisco prices and service was decent. Overall a decent dining experiences. Possibly a good location for date night due to the dim lighting.
author: Diane T.

description: This place was très délicieux! Stopped in for brunch before a Saturday matinee at the Orpheum. Great location, street parking was easy. The crêpes were so delicious and very authentic! Tasted just like they did in France. Mimosa+crêpe and you can't go wrong! Also the French-style outdoor seating is totally Insta-worthy!
author: Callie H.

description:
I had a seriously long day at work, and it wasn't even over yet when my coworker and I dined at Chez Maman West for lunch.  I ordered the salmon crepe and french onion soup.

The soup was delicious!  It was rich with the right amount of cheese and bread.  The broth had a really good flavor, and the onions were caramelized just right.  The salmon crepe came with creme fraiche, spinach, and shallots, along with the side salad.  The soup made me a bit full, but I still managed to finish the crepe (not so much the side salad comprised of arugula).  

The atmosphere reminded me of the cafes in Paris: small, busy, and intimate.  My coworker and I enjoyed the waiter's accent, who was very attentive and friendly.

I want to come back soon to try more from their lunch menu, and also brunch.
author: Vira P.

description: We got at the restaurant at around 5p and got seated right away. First time at the restaurant so asked our server for his recommendation. He recommended the porkchop and brussel sprouts. It was delicious. Paired it with the cab-
author: Ro N.

description: I ate here last night with my boyfriend after wandering around searching for a place to eat. So happy we stopped by. I was about to write my name on the clipboard and the hostess was very attentive and since we were a small party of 2, we got seated right away outside. I ordered the chicken and my boyfriend ordered the salmon with mashed potatoes. My chicken was amazing and the sauce was divine. Lemony herbed goodness. We ordered dessert and I got the chocolate mousse and my dude got the creme brûlée. Both were super delicious. The service was wonderful too. 5 stars and will definitely come back in the future.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Chez Maman is a very cozy bistro with a nice bar serving delicious food. I am a big fan of their Basic Burger which the waiter will strongly insist be served medium rare.  For food safety reasons, at most other burger places, I usually get my burgers cooked well, but they always insist that medium rare is the way to go, and I figure that it's safe since they serve a lot of beef tartare.  At any rate, their burger served medium rare with Roquefort cheese is amazing, and is one of the very best burgers in The City.  

I'm also a big fan of their steak frites - which not surprisingly they will also insist on serving medium rare. The steak is perfectly seasoned, and the peppercorn sauce compliments it perfectly. The fries accompanying the steak are nice and crisp and go very well with the aioli on the side. 

I've also tried their veal, which is also very good, but the garlic wine sauce that comes with it is amazing.  I had to ask for extra bread to mop it all up. 

I've been to Chez Maman 4 times since "discovering" about a month ago, and I'm slowly making my way through the menu. So far, every meal that I've had here has been fantastic, and I'm looking forward to going back.
author: Allen T.

description:
We have a table outside and it was nice having lunch  outside of the restaurant at Haye Valley. We were there to celebrate my friend's birthday . I order the salmon paninis with salad. it was really good and the food was yummy,  I think the portion is very good side.

I would love to come back again for lunch or brunch.
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Very good French cuisine. Fresh products and very well done. A must go if you want to have a great cuisine with simplicity and in a great ambiance!
Feel like in a Parisian brasserie
Great job!
author: Arnaud A.

description: Chez Maman is still by far one of my favorite French restaurant in the city! Parking is a pain in the butt but the food is worth it ;-) I love the French onion soup and beef tartare. Husband and I usually get the large size for the beef tartare. Still love the mussels and fries! If you still have room by the end of your dinner, get the chocolate gelato. It's amazing ;-)
author: jessica t.

description: Pretty good food.  Wasn't thrilled about the extra 3% charge added to the tax line item.
author: mrharb w.

description:
Cute bistro in Hayes Valley. The "yum" factor can range from 3 to 4 stars. In my experience, it really depends on what you order! 

The Beef Tartare - 4 stars.
Incredibly fresh and delicious. The beef was seasoned with chopped onions, cornichons, and either peppercorn or mustard seeds. Whatever it was, it was tasty and the mince on the tartare was just right, topped with a quail egg and served with toast points for your eating pleasure. 

The Escargot - 2 stars
Very pretty to look at, but the escargot lacked texture and flavor (I've had better). It was just a mushy, garlic bomb. Bleh. I would not recommend this appetizer.
author: Chase B.

description: Good food. My boyfriend loved the pork chop. They were really flexible with my gluten-free diet, and easily accommodated it. They had a few gluten free options, and I had a delicious fish dish. Make a reservation, it gets crowded!
author: Rachel M.

description: Owner is so nice and food is amazing! I had the Nicoise with salmon and the Pain Perdu my friends had the salmon panini with vanilla gelato and croque Monsieur and everything was delicious! Will definitely return.
author: Marie T.

description:
Mussels were excellent. Service was prompt but not pushy at all. We got a table on the sidewalk and needed quick
Service due to theater tx. The staff performed perfectly. And my burger was excellent as were all three of the other meals.  Perfect pre-Orpheum or Pre-Jazz spot. Walking distance to Orpheum or Jazz Center. Can't wait to go back.
author: Alan P.

description:
We come here with my wife for my French fix once or twice a month. The food is always delicious, and affordable for SF, staff is friendly. 
The downside is they don't take reservation so we often have to wait some time to get a table.
author: Julien B.

description:
The best escargot I've had thus far in California! 

I had dinner here with 3 other sexy friends and we thoroughly enjoyed our time here. Only thing that was missing was a full bar menu versus just beer and wine. 

Appetizers were pretty good, but the winner was definitely the Escargot. Beef tartare was just okay and thee salad we all shared was decent too (nothing too wow).

I'd have to say my dinner was DELISH. Ordered the Flat Iron Steak with french fries and green peppercorn sauce. Best steak I've had in awhile to be honest!

When we first sat down, service felt like it was about a B- rating. Once our wine and food finally came out service went back up to an A for me (especially for that eye candy second waiter or host that came out and explained how to eat Escargot to my girlfriend).
author: Michelle V.

description: Walked up and got seated outside on a Monday night. Ordered the mussels, a panini, and truffle mac and cheese for two share. Good service and delicious food.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Last two trips: May 2017 and Aug (1st) 2017. 

Chez Maman has transformed itself from Good to Average to Below Average. The service is still very good. But not much to say after that.

Items eaten in the last couple of trips:

Nicoise salad: low quality ingredients, excessive dressing (this used to be pretty good in the old days)

Salmon burger: salmon quality not the best; unevenly cooked. The fries are not that great any more.

Regular burger: below average beef quality

Unlikely I will ever return. Too many choices on Hayes to come back to mediocrity.

Sorry guys - you need to up your game.
author: noflaps c.

description: We got take-out for lunch: paninis and salad.  They were so good we came back for dinner.  This is an unpretentious French place which makes its analogues in France look bad by comparison.  They said the moules were good, and they weren't kidding.
author: John S.

description: This place is all right, the crepe and benedicts are really good and the price is okay for a French inspired cuisine at least for brunch. The only thing is that it is difficult to find parking and it is a long wait because the cafe is so small
author: Han S.

description: Hamburger (added cheddar cheese and bacon) was delicious!!  Ordered to go and provided with the option of coming with fries, salad, or combo.  I asked for all fries and got a combo, but no big deal.  Burger is served on a ciabatta bun, which tastes great and holds up well to a juicy burger, but makes the hamburger itself look small. . definitely had a few bites of just bread, but the hamburger patty is thick and juicy.  The added bacon was crispy and a generous portion.  I definitely plan on ordering again!
author: Katie H.

description: GET THE PORK CHOPS! Get ready for a little Pari ambiance and food coma. I'm a sucker for atmosphere and good eats. Friendly staff and owner.
author: TJ S.

description:
I have to say, my high hope of their famous must-try burger only made my experience here worse:( I ordered the most popular medium-rare beef patty, which was hopelessly tasteless... I admit that I was half full when it's brought to the table, but it should entice my appetite and not suppress it further more. I also added cheese and mushrooms to flavor it up, which made me only want to scratch them from the burger... 

Ok enough complaints. The reason I gave 3 stars is because their brilliant and fresh mussels and not too long waiting.
author: Yuhuan T.

description: Stumbled into this place by chance on our last day in the area while on a business trip. I love French food and was excited at the sight of the menu. Ordered a riesling, escargot (my favourite), and the salmon with fingerling potatoes and was not disappointed even a little bit. The food was exquisite, and it was such a pleasant surprise for the small, corner restaurant. Staff was extremely friendly and attentive, and the ambiance is more relaxed than I'm used to for a French restaurant - a welcome distinguishing characteristic. Prices were about expected for the quality of the food, and we couldn't have left with fuller or happier tummies. I will most certainly be returning!
author: Brittany O.

description: First, we came and sat down with dirty plates on the table. Second, we asked for the mussels to be over cooked, the waiter questioned and asked us what do you mean by over cooked ?! Third, I ordered food together with my friend but her food came 30 minutes before me. I asked them where's my food and he questioned me back, what do you mean!!? So technically I waited 30 minutes for a plate of food. Lastly, we also ordered a crepe and it tasted bitter. I feel like they could've done better and have better quality.
author: K. O.

description: Went here for lunch today and thought it was ok. I got the chicken panini with the salad. My friend got a crepe and he liked it but wasn't blown away. I'd recommend it if you're looking for an affordable French restaurant with decent food but I don't recommend getting the chicken panini as it's a bit bland.
author: Mira B.

description: This is such a sweet spot to grab brunch in the city! They serve delicious bread while you wait, and have great specials on mimosas.
author: Samantha B.

description:
Oh my god. Get the burger. 

Arrive here at approx. 7pm on a Thursday after drinking a bottle of wine at one of the many cute wine bars nearby, and magically get a table for 2 outside, right under the heater. Tell the waiter that you want to share the burger with swiss, and you want both the fries and salad as a side. (They have other options for cheese, but who puts brie on a burger?)

5 mins later, free bread.

5 mins after that, a beautiful burger, split perfectly in half between 2 plates. 

25 mins later. Saunter out, full of delicious food. Satisfied. Happy.
author: Steph D.

description: Love this place! Probably my favorite place for French cuisine, especially because it's affordable compared to other French restaurants. Without fail, I always order the mariniere mussels and a side of fries with aioli. The wine sauce is so good that you'll feel like drinking it like a soup. I definitely dip my French fries in the sauce too! Speaking of the French fries, the aioli sauce is one of the best Paolo sauces I've had yet. I come during off times to avoid a wait.
author: Lexi R.

description:
Seated myself at the bar for dinner. Friendly bartender, warm and friendly atmosphere. All staffs were very busy and move very fast as all tables are full and people are waiting outside, but no sour faces, the staffs are all smiling. 
Tried their Moules mariniere (mussels in white wine) with les frites (french fries) and found it was as good as the one in Brittany, France. Good selection of French wine & tap beers. French style baguette & butter come with the dish. Very glad to stumble on this authentic French style bistro in the great Hayes Valley neighborhood.
Will definitely return and recommend to anyone!
author: Charles K.

description: Service was rushed. Long wait but that's not surprising. The crepe with salmon was quite good topped with arugala. The mussels with white wine and parsley were subtle and tasty but a small portion. Sever brought all the food at once and rushed us to finish. With better service and also with better care taken of the wine which tasted not fresh this could be a better experience. Still it was enjoyable for dinner.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Staff was friendly. Place is cozy. Good food is served :)
Ordered a pork chop and poulette. Both was extremely delicious. The poulette is extremely recommended if you love mussels. There's little to none smell comes from the mussels.
author: Tjong A.

description: I'm ambivalent about this place. I have friends who go absolutely nuts for their dishes, but I'm just not that into it. I have long since discovered that I don't like savory crépes, not even Chez Maman was able to change my attitude on that, so maybe that is half of the reason why I'm not so entranced. But then the other menu items aren't that impressive either. I have tried their Fettuccini pasta and Mussels in various sauces. They are decent but not particularly notable. The good thing about Chez Maman is that their line is usually pretty short. Certainly a plus when you are looking for food on a Friday night and everybody is having hour-long wait estimates... They charge reasonably too. I wouldn't mind going back there from time to time, just not something I would be super excited to bring people to try out.
author: Angel C.

description:
Chez Mamon  is like eating at a street corner cafe in Paris. The Moules et Frite (Mussels and fries) is superb. The chicken was delicious: tasty and moist. Very authentic place. Our waiter was actually from Paris, so there was that.
The only negative I would have is the Croque Monsieur was better at The Butler & The Chef on South Park.
author: I M.

description:
"When life hands you lemons, use them as garnish"

Food and great company can turn sour situations to a sweet one.  Arrived here around 12:30 pm on a lovely Saturday afternoon and we waited about 5 minutes before being seated, surprisingly.  Filling up my belly with good food and my mind with positive thoughts was much needed.

Thai Mussles and Fries - I love the mussels here - tasty and plentiful.  Fries are delish
Brussel Sprouts - Cooked perfectly, great flavor
Savoyarde Crepe - nothing special
Croque Monsieur - Cheesy, great fresh salad

The crepe and croque weren't necessary.  Not that we were full but those dishes could've been replaced with something tastier.  Service was great.
author: Linda N.

description: Excellent mussels, frites and smokes salmon panini topped with salted caramel gelato. Wonderful ambiance and attentive service. Oh, and the Kir Royale was great too!
author: Kathryn S.

description: Fantastic mussels....nice folks, even if your French is rusty....good beer! Nuff said.
author: Bill H.

description:
Went here when I was visiting San Francisco as recommended by a friend and it did not disappoint!

The escargot is great, the french onion soup is everything, and the pork chop, huge serving and to die for. All reasonably priced. Would definitely come back!!!
author: Joseph E.

description:
My girlfriend and I randomly stumbled across this place on Yelp and were happy that we tried it. It's a popular place with limited seating and a long wait. Luckily, you can put your name and number down and they will call you when your table is ready. I think we caught them on an off day as we accidently got the table next to us food (we ordered the same thing), and the service was slow. It's ok though, because we made friends with the table next to us. O

Overall the experience was great. The food was flavorful, well balanced and we made new friends. I would come back to try more things.

What we ordered:

Les moules: Marinière: Garlic, White Wine, Lemon Juice & Parsley..... I felt that the muscles were small, but the sauce was great. Well balanced and not overly salty. Great to dip your bread in, so don't let them take the pot.

Beef Tartare & Dijon Mustard, Capers, Shallots, Quail Egg, Toast Points... I personally like the my tartare a little more fine, but still great. 

Chez Maman burgers with Bacon and Avacado... Great flavor and a ton of food. Not a place you would think would have a tasty burger.
author: Long N.

description:
I had brunch here on a Saturday around 11:30 AM. With four of us we only had to wait about 15 minutes, we took the first available table which was outside. Sitting outside in Hayes Valley is always nice. Except it was a little too hot and the awnings here could be larger. As they are now, they do not actually provide any shade. We spent the first part of our meal putting on sunscreen. Also the tables are silver, so we kept our menus to stop the reflective surface from blinding us. 
The food was good, I personally didn't eat a ton b/c I'm trying not to eat meat or dairy. Not a ton of options there, but the Bloody Mary I had was great #Vegan. I did enjoy that they brought out a bread basket, carbs are the universal language. All my friends enjoyed their meals, good portions for the prices.
Service could have been a little faster. We wanted to get the check handled fast since the sunscreen was wearing thin and we were roasting. Had to flag down the hostess to get it. 
Long story short: Be wary of sitting outside If it's hot and don't be a vegan, but an adorable french place.
author: Emily D.

description:
Great food and even better service. Stopped by with a large party and received complementary fries w/ aioli for the long wait. They were delicious, btw! The host was incredibly attentive and kept checking up on us to let us know about how much longer it would be. I didn't catch his name but he was an attractive young fellow (LOL). The waiters were also super attentive and accommodating though we had a large party, which completely surpassed my expectations. They didn't even charge us 18% gratuity bc of the wait. Now that's some good service. 

Ordered the salmon medium-rare and it was cooked perfectly! Super tender, soft, and flavorful. Also had a french onion soup on the side and it was the best french onion soup I've ever had....ever. It is a MUST TRY!!!! Tried out my bf's lamb and it was a bit on the gamey side for me but he loved it. Decided to get the creme brûlée for dessert and enjoyed it, though it was a bit on the eggy side. 

Really enjoyed my experience here. I'm definitely going to have to stop by again to try everything else on the menu!
author: Marny N.

description: Great french onion soup here. That + a croque madame makes for a hearty meal. Fries are worth ordering as well. Nice little seating on the street.
author: J A.

description: The owner went out of his way to ensure he did everything he could to make us feel welcome.
author: Dee B.

description: Felt like wanting to get some French food so just came. Delicious food great service. Will come again!
author: Lancelot L.

description:
Came here for lunch a week or two ago. Surprisingly easy to find parking, and only had to wait about 15-20 minutes for a table for two inside. 

We ordered the steak, escargot, carbonara pasta, fries, and white wine mussels. The escargot was delicious, not too hard and the flavor was great. The carbonara pasta was kind of heavy, I felt super fat after eating it, but it was not bad. Their fries were really good, thin and oily, just like McDonald's fries, the ultimate fries standard. The mussels were good, but so small. Luckily they gave a lot. The steak was perfectly cooked, I really liked it.

Service was pretty good, food was on the pricier side, paid about $80 total, and didn't have any drinks.
author: Sean W.

description:
I'm not much for doing reviews however since I love good food and am lucky enough to be at "the table" in a number of great spots around the bay I thought I'd start weighing in occasionally.

This was my first visit to Chez Maman and it felt very much like a small French restaurant would. Busy, lively, focused on food but not always the patrons. Cordial but not friendly.

The food was excellent the pork chop was superb moist yet cooked - sauce and vegetables wonderful. The bread crusty and firm on the outside but moist and chewy inside.

Everything I saw being served looked wonderful - including the presentation which was more than food on a plate. All in all I'd think you would enjoy!
author: Steve B.

description:
Now I know why everyone who's been here tells me that it's just okay. 

Went here the other night and ordered the mussels with the white wine and lemon with fries, the beef tartare and the sea bass. Other than the bass, nothing had any flavor to it. The broth to the mussels tasted like flavored water and the mussels themselves were just meh. The tartare was pretty bland as well- I've definitely tasted better. 

While the food was really subpar, the service deserves 5 stars. Everyone was very accommodating and even moved us when we asked for a larger table when we were originally squeezed onto a two top. 

As for drinks, they have wine and beer only- but the pours were veryyyyy generous!
author: Mandi W.

description:
A delightful steak fritte. The fries were perfect. There was a little book rare in a little bit tough for my liking, but the flavor was excellent as was the sauce. I love the setting there, especially the outdoor seating on a lovely evening

The only pain is that they don't take reservations, so on a Saturday night even when I arrived at 6 I had to wait a half an hour for a table for two
author: David A R.

description:
have been waiting to try this second location foreverrrr since visiting the original chez maman about 5 years ago?! YIKES. great location in hayes, which is super cute and somewhere I need to visit more often.  we came around 11:3 this past sunday and there was miraculously no wait! so key is to get here earlier than later I guess, cuz when I walked by two hours later, the restaurant was packed. 

we ordered a pitcher of sangria to start ($26) as we waited by the bar to peruse the menu and wait for our friends to show up.  sangria was good! during brunch - they have a separate more 'brunch-y' menu but the regular menu items are all available! AMAZING!  I was gonna get the burger but definitely have a soft spot for croquet madames, so I got that instead.  of course there was French onion soup, so my friend and I both got that to start. 

everything came out surprisingly quickly! the plates all looked sooo beautiful and smelled even more so.  the quantity of food for the prices is out of this world! my $13 croque madame with a side salad was HUGE (but I ate it all) and the soup was PACKED with cheese and yummy onion.  my friends and I couldn't be happier with the quality of the food either - great vegetarian options as well!  service was average - got a bit spotty as they got busier later in the brunch hours.  need to come back soon for the burger!!
author: Christina L.

description: Very nice place overall. My favorite items are the Thai mussels and the half roasted chicken with lemon confit. The steak is also very good. These are very nicely done. The burger is ok. Seating outside is very nice but will be a wait if it's a nice day. Overall give a solid recommendation
author: Anant P.

description: I Love this spot!!  have been for years - the food is spot on - the service very friendly & efficient- my favs are the mushroom crepes the warm goat cheese arugula salad & the mussels - great wines by the glass!!
author: Maribeth G.

description: French restaurant not too expensive for once. Lovely service. The food is simple and very good. We went on a Saturday night and it was very busy. The wait was about 40min. Inside it's small and cozy. They also have tables outside.
author: Cecile M.

description:
Chez Maman always has a long wait time - if I get in within 20 minutes, I consider myself lucky! I find that the wait is a symptom of their good food, bustling lively atmosphere, and friendly service. I usually get their burger, which is great with brie cheese, and always well-cooked (I get mine medium). I find the wine selection friendly and not overwhelming, and their pours are generous. 

My husband and I have been at least 5-6 times, but we always end up at the bar because we prefer earlier seating to a table chair. Go here if you're looking for a quality dining experience with a friend or for a casual date.
author: S O.

description:
Review is for the extremely rude management/owner in street clothes.

My party of 3 waited for 45 minutes for a table. The host then asked if we were okay sitting outside and we said that was fine. He proceeded to push two small tables (each table alone would only fit 2 people max) together for us. As we sat down, the owner or manager in street clothes came barging out yelling at us. Literally as we were in the process of sitting down he began pulling the table apart saying we could not sit there. We said the host just sat us there and he said he made a mistake and that's not how it works here, in the most condescending and rude tone I have come across at a restaurant.

We walked back to wait in front of the restaurant in shock and decided to keep waiting since everything else in the area was busy and it had already been an hour. The manager/owner kept trying to seat the other groups of three (2 other groups of 3 behind us) at the tables for 2 and each group refused as the table was only big enough for 2. After 15-20 minutes a group of 4 came up and the manager/owner let them skip the line to push the two small tables together outside. All the other groups of 3 had to keep waiting while a group of 4 skipped ahead simply because he didn't want one chair to be open. That was the last straw and we left along with our business.

In the end, it wasn't that big of a deal if he was simply polite. If he apologized for the mistake and explained the situation calmly we would have been more understanding... However, I have never been talked to like that or treated like that at a restaurant and I am still appalled. I will never be back to spend money at this restaurant.

If you look through some of the other reviews you'll see many other customers have had similar experiences with this owner/manager. Shouldn't be acceptable for a place that requires customer services.
author: KC W.

description:
Chez Maman West has that French/American appeal to it. A typical Hayes Valley restaurant with tiny tables and not a whole lot of sitting, Chez Maman West is pretty full, but somehow, they keep the rotation going pretty fast. Trying to impress my brother in the ways of San Francisco, I decided on this place in Hayes Valley. The wait was only 10 minutes for a Thursday night. The two person table is pretty tight to another table, but nothing out of the ordinary for San Francisco restaurants. 

FOOD: Poulette Mussels. Grilled Salmon. 

The mussels had that umami taste to them. Perhaps it's the taste of the sea with shallots and the white wine or something, but the sauce was reduced beautifully. Not a very overpowering flavor, but everything in the sauce is great. Flavoring the mussels and cooking them to perfection, the mussels were amazing. A definite order here (and make sure to use your bread to get the last bits of sauce at the bottom)! 

The grilled salmon I was less impressed with. The fish was cooked well and the potatoes were fine, but I did not find this dish to wow me. I was a little underwhelmed.  

SERVICE: Quick! 

Overall, I do find the place pricier than other French/American cuisine places I have been to, but it does come with a San Francisco price tag. Overall, very delicious and would highly recommend this restaurant in the Hayes Valley area.
author: Albert H.

description:
Now that I have a few data points, I can write a review without feeling so judge-y.

Chez Maman is central to Hayes Valley, super cute and cafe-like. I love the wood finishes and natural light that seeps into the restaurant. It's pretty intimate, I can see it being quite romantic in the evening. Something I'd imagine you'd find in Paris.
